caseTitle: ARTHUR v. JOHN HECTOR ANSAH & NAOMI OWUSU
summary: In Ruth Arthur v. John Hector Ansah & Naomi Owusu, the Ghanaian Court of Appeal upheld the High Court's ruling that a customary marriage between Ruth Arthur and John Hector Ansah remained legally valid and subsisting despite a subsequent ordinance marriage between Ansah and Naomi Owusu in 1998. The court found that the customary marriage had not been properly dissolved according to Akan customary law, which requires a formal process involving both families, libation, and the application of kaolin. The appellant failed to provide satisfactory evidence that these procedures were followed. Although the parties had separated and lived apart for years, the court emphasized that legal dissolution requires adherence to prescribed formalities. The ordinance marriage was declared null and void, and the appeal was dismissed, affirming that a marriage cannot be dissolved informally or by mere abandonment.
verdict: Appeal dismissed; ordinance marriage declared null and void due to subsisting customary marriage.
citations: In Re Yendi Skin Affairs: Yakubu vrs. Abdulai (No.2) 1984-86 2 GLR 239 SC
Log & Lumber Ltd. vrs. Oppong 1977 2 GLR 263 CA
John Mensah Sarba's Fanti Customary Law 3rd Edition p.52
rationaleHighlights: Customary marriage dissolution requires formal procedure including family meeting, libation, and kaolin application.
Burden of proof for dissolution lies with the party alleging it.
Failure to follow customary procedure renders dissolution invalid.
Marriage remains legally valid even if de facto ended without formalities.
Appellate court defers to trial judge's factual findings when supported by evidence.
False declaration of marital status ('single') on ordinance marriage invalidates subsequent marriage if prior marriage subsists.
Publication of banns ineffective where intended party was unaware due to limited posting.
Legal formalities cannot be bypassed by mutual abandonment of marital duties.
